title: 6.2: Vector Operations
summary: Learn advanced vector operations including length calculations and vector math
intro: In this lesson, you'll learn advanced vector operations for particle systems. You'll create a complete particle system from scratch that demonstrates vector length calculations, normalization, and how to use vector math to create sophisticated particle behaviors.
steps: Create a <filter-value>System</filter-value> block - this is the root of your particle system
Add a <filter-value>Texture</filter-value> block to provide a texture for the particles and connect to System block
Load a texture <textures>flare.png</textures> by load button in the Texture block properties
Add a <filter-value>CreateParticle</filter-value> block to emit particles and connect to System block
Add a <filter-value>Color4</filter-value> block and set its value to a base color
Connect the Color4 block's output to CreateParticle block's color input
Add a <filter-value>Float</filter-value> block and set its value for base size
Connect the Float block's output to CreateParticle block's size input
Add a <filter-value>CylinderShape</filter-value> block to emit particles from a cylinder volume and connect between CreateParticle and System blocks
Add <filter-value>UpdatePosition</filter-value> block after CylinderShape and connect to System block
Add a <filter-value>Position</filter-value> block to get the particle's current position
Add a <filter-value>Scaled Direction</filter-value> block to get the particle's scaled direction
Add a math <filter-value>Add</filter-value> block to calculate new position (Position + Scaled Direction)
Connect Position block to Add block's left input and Scaled Direction block to right input
Connect Add block's output to UpdatePosition block's position input
Add a <filter-value>VectorLength</filter-value> block (ParticleVectorLengthBlock) to calculate the length of the direction vector
Connect Scaled Direction block to VectorLength block's vector input
Add a <filter-value>Float</filter-value> block for size factor and set its value (e.g., 0.5)
Add a math <filter-value>Multiply</filter-value> block to multiply vector length by size factor
Connect VectorLength block's output to Multiply block's left input and size factor Float to right input
Add <filter-value>UpdateColor</filter-value> block after UpdatePosition and connect InitialColor contextual value to it
Add <filter-value>UpdateSize</filter-value> block after UpdateColor and combine base size with the size multiplier from Multiply block
Connect UpdateSize output to System block
Observe how particle size varies based on movement speed

blocks.name: ParticleVectorLengthBlock
blocks.description: Calculates the length (magnitude) of a vector. Useful for distance calculations, speed measurements, and vector normalization. In the visual editor, you can find this block in the block list and configure its properties in the properties panel on the right.

properties.name: vector
properties.description: The vector whose length will be calculated. Connect a Vector3 output to this input.

properties.name: length
properties.description: The calculated length of the vector. Use this output for distance or speed calculations.

codeCopy: Vector operations are essential for advanced particle effects. ParticleVectorLengthBlock calculates the magnitude of a vector, which represents distance or speed. This can be used to create effects where particle properties (like size or color) change based on how fast the particle is moving. The formula for vector length is: length = sqrt(x² + y² + z²).
objectives: Calculate vector lengths for distance and speed measurements
Use vector length to affect particle properties
Combine vector operations with other calculations
Apply vector math to create sophisticated effects

commonMistakes.explanation: Vector length is always positive (distance). Using it directly for effects that need negative values or specific ranges can cause issues.
commonMistakes.solution: If you need normalized values or specific ranges, multiply or divide the length by appropriate factors. Remember: length is always >= 0.

commonMistakes.mistake: Not understanding what vector length represents
commonMistakes.explanation: Vector length represents distance or magnitude, not direction. It's a scalar value, not a vector.
commonMistakes.solution: Use vector length for distance-based effects, speed calculations, or when you need to normalize vectors. For direction, use the vector itself.

homework: Create particles that change color based on speed
Use vector length to create distance-based effects
Combine vector length with age-based calculations
Experiment with normalizing vectors for consistent directions
Create effects where size varies with movement speed
